Award.AwardTitle: Geochemical Analysis of Fluid Inclusions in Trace and Minor Mississippi Valley-type Zn-Pb Occurrences in the US Mid-continent: Implications for Crustal Metal Enrichment Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mississippi River watershed of the central U.S. hosts numerous deposits of lead and zinc ranging from the world-class Southeast Missouri and Tri-State (Oklahoma-Missouri-Kansas) mining districts to widely dispersed non-commercial traces of mineralization. Collectively these deposits are referred to as 'Mississippi Valley-type' (MVT) and occur as sulfide minerals that were precipitated in limestone and dolomite host rocks by highly saline groundwater (about 10 times more saline than seawater) at temperatures between 80 and 150Â° C. The largest deposits are in the Southeast Missouri district, which currently account for about 70% of primary lead production and about 6.5% of primary zinc production in the U.S. The Tri-State district was mined commercially from 1848 to 1970 and during its peak in the early 20th century accounted for as much as about 60% of primary zinc and 11% of primary lead production in the U.S. Recent research carried out by the principal investigators and their collaborators has revealed the chemical composition of the groundwater that precipitated the MVT ores in the Southeast Missouri and Tri-State districts and other formerly commercial deposits in northern Arkansas and central Missouri. This research showed that large MVT ore deposits in the central U.S. formed from groundwater with high concentrations of lead, high Ca/Na and K/Na ratios, low Ca/Mg ratios, and that was chemically reducing. The purpose of the present research project is to determine whether groundwater that formed trace and minor MVT mineralization had the same composition as the groundwater that formed large ore bodies. This information would be useful in determining the commercial potential of new MVT deposit discoveries and in determining the geologic processes responsible for concentrating metals into large ore bodies.

The project will be carried out by analyzing fluid inclusions, tiny (< 0.1 mm in diameter) samples of ambient groundwater trapped in the precipitated MVT deposit minerals. The locations of numerous trace occurrences of MVT mineralization have been compiled from the published literature and will be visited and sampled by the principal investigators. Slices of the rock samples will be cut and polished to 0.05 to 0.1 mm thicknesses to make the fluid inclusions visible by transmitted light microscopy. Fluid inclusions will first be studied using microthermometry to determine their bulk salinity from their melting point depression and their trapping temperature from the point of phase homogenization. The presence of methane, carbon dioxide, sulfate, and hydrogen sulfide will be sought in the fluid inclusions using Raman spectroscopy and will constrain the redox potential of the mineralizing groundwater and depth of mineral deposit formation. The concentrations of elements like Li, Na, Mg, K, Ca, Mn, Fe, Cu, Zn, Sr, Ba, and Pb will be determined from laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) and will be used to see if groundwater that formed the trace MVT occurrences has the same chemical signature as groundwater that formed the large MVT ore deposits. More specifically, the data acquired from this research will allow two fundamental hypotheses for the origin of MVT deposits to be tested: (1) That anomalously metal-rich, high Ca/Na and K/Na, and low Ca/Mg fluids are needed to form large MVT ore deposits, (2) that redox conditions at the trace and minor occurrences of MVT mineralization were locally too oxidizing to allow much of the sulfur, whether resident or delivered by invading fluid, to exist as sulfide rather than sulfate, which would inhibit sulfide mineral precipitation and deposit growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The purpose of this research project was to identify the geochemical conditions that promote the formation of large Mississippi Valley-type (MVT) ore deposits.  MVT deposits occur throughout the world at scales ranging from trace occurrences of no more than a few grams to giant ore deposits of hundreds of millions of tonnes.  Regardless of their size, MVT deposits are consistently hosted by limestone or dolomite and contain variable proportions of the minerals sphalerite (ZnS), galena (PbS), pyrite/marcasite (FeS2), barite (BaSO4), fluorite (CaF2), calcite (CaCO3), dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2), and quartz (SiO2).  MVT deposits of all sizes are also known to have precipitated from saline groundwater generally at elevated temperatures between ~80 and 150° C.  The Mississippi River watershed of the central U.S., i.e. the mid-continent of North America, hosts the type examples of the MVT deposit class and some of the largest MVT deposits in the world.  In addition, the region hosts countless trace MVT occurrences.  The region is thus ideal for testing general concepts about MVT deposit formation. 

 The compositions of the fluids that formed the large MVT ore deposits in the mid-continent have been well characterized in previous studies.  In contrast, prior to the present study, the composition of the fluids that formed trace MVT occurrences in the mid-continent had not been well characterized.  The main goal of the present study, therefore, was to characterize the composition and temperature of the fluids that formed trace MVT occurrences through analysis of fluid inclusions.  A complementary goal was to measure the Pb and S isotope and chemical compositions of sulfide mineral matrices in the trace MVT occurrences, which provide an indirect indicator of fluid composition.  These new data for trace MVT occurrences could then be compared to existing data for MVT ore deposits to seek any systematic differences that might provide insights into the factors that promote or limit MVT deposit growth. 

The study identified four systematic differences between trace MVT occurrences and MVT ore deposits.  (1) Fluid inclusion homogenization temperatures (a minimum estimate of mineral formation temperature) were found generally to be slightly lower in trace MVT occurrences than in mid-continent MVT ore deposits.  (2) Fluid inclusions in trace MVT occurrences were found to have low concentrations of methane whereas fluid inclusions in MVT ore deposits have high reported methane concentrations.  (3) Although trace MVT occurrences have highly radiogenic Pb, their Pb tends to be less radiogenic than the Pb in MVT ore deposits.  (4) Trace MVT occurrences on the whole have isotopically lighter sulfur than MVT ore deposits.    

In other respects, the study found trace MVT occurrences and MVT ore deposits to resemble one another.  These include the salinities and elemental compositions of sphalerite-hosted fluid inclusions, and trace metal concentrations in sphalerite matrices.   

None of the direct or inferred differences in fluid composition and temperature found between trace MVT occurrences and MVT ore deposits in the present study are large enough to account for the orders of magnitude difference in their scale.  On the whole, the fluids that formed trace MVT occurrences are not very different from the fluids that formed MVT ore deposits with respect to the parameters measured.  This observation points to differences in the local availability of aqueous sulfide, which was not measurable with the methods used in the present study, as a likely explanation for the difference in scale between trace MVT occurrences and MVT ore deposits.  Sites of trace MVT and MVT ore deposit formation were probably visited by fluids of similar overall composition, including metal content, but only at sites where local sulfide abundance was high and could react with these fluids could large MVT ore deposits form.

       

Broader Impacts

The project has several broader impacts beyond its stated academic objectives.  Because the MVT deposits in the North American mid-continent are highly representative of MVT deposits worldwide, the project results have implications for MVT deposit formation worldwide.  That is, a likely valid inference from the present project is that large MVT ore deposits tend to form at sites where metal-bearing, saline groundwater is able to react with locally abundant sulfide.  The results of the project may benefit exploration for undiscovered ore deposits in the mid-continent and possibly elsewhere in that prospective MVT ore deposits are likely to have isotopically heavier sulfur and more radiogenic lead than small MVT deposits.  The project provided training for three undergraduate students at the University of Missouri—Kansas City (Lance Martin, Kristina Gale, and Julien Roskham), two of whom are members of underrepresented demographic groups in the geological sciences.  In addition, the project supported the doctoral dissertation of Joshua Field and the master’s theses of Stuart Kenderes and Sarah Smith.  All three of these students were at the University of Missouri—Columbia, and one is a member of an underrepresented demographic group in the geological sciences.
